strIntroduction: Let's enjoy a party in Japan and make Japanese friends who can speak English. After making friends, they will tell you many things about Japan. We do this cultural exchange party once a month. * Only Dec 18th Party will start from 14pm. (not night time) Schedule Time: The reception opens at 19:30 pm. Staff helps to break the ice for meeting people. Enjoy the conversations while drinking. If we have time, we sometimes do some games. The party ends at 22:00 pm. It's a friendly, easy-going party. Even you can join alone. At the end of the party, you'll have made many friends here. We look forward to seeing you!
strTitle: Join a Cultural Exchange & International Party

strIntroduction: Come learn about the exciting world of Japanese paper Washi and enjoy traditional Japanese culture at the Japanese Paper Factory in Nihonbashi! At Ozu Japanese Paper Factory, founded in 1653, there is a Japanese paper making studio on the first floor, as well as a store where people can purchase many different kinds of Japanese paper which come from many different areas of Japan. There are many various kinds of Japanese paper, which are used for a variety of purposes, such as: painting, calligraphy, crafts, and decorating interiors. On the second floor, there are various exhibitions held, including calligraphy exhibitions, painting exhibitions, and collage exhibitions, where you can see various works. Finally, on the third floor you can find the Ozu museum, where you can learn about the history of the paper from the Edo period. Main Features: We have a Japanese paper workshop, where you can have fun making paper, and can make a unique work of art unlike anything else on Earth! You can have fun here with both friends and family. However, it’s perfectly fine to go at it as a solo traveler and focus on the craft. Those who have experienced our workshop always come back again and again for more! One workshop can accommodate from 1 to 10 people at the same time. (The required time for one workshop is approx. 1 hour. The entry fee is included in the tour price per person which includes your own A4 size piece of paper that you make at the factory and can bring home with you.) Workshop Time Slots: Monday to Friday: 10:30, 11:30, 14:00, 15:00, 16:00 Saturday: 10:30, 11:30, 14:00, 15:00. After the workshop is over, you can check out our gallery or visit our store. Japanese paper has the warm and gentle power to create powerful bonds among people. Truly a great spot to enjoy the traditional culture of Japan!
strTitle: 80% OFF Learn traditional culture at the Paper Factory,Tokyo

strIntroduction: Do you know "Depachika"? In Japanese, "Depachika" refers to basement floor of department store, where the delicatessen and various food sections are usually located. "Depachika" is the combination of “depa” which is the abbreviation of department store, and "chika" which means basement in Japanese. It's really fun and fascinating popular place, but if you don't speak Japanese, it's sometimes difficult to understand descriptions. In this tour, a friendly and English speaking professional guide introduce "Depachika" of Nihonbashi Takashimaya which is one of famous and lond-established department stores in Japan. Let's enjoy "Depachika" food and culture with a friendly guide! ◯Schedule: 12:30pm Meet your local guide at in front of Takashimaya Nihonbashi. -Team building -Explore basement floor "Depachika" ,taste sampling and buy some side dishes -Walk around other floor -Eat and drink at roof top floor 2:30pm Finish at sroof top Includes Food/Drink -Special sampling at "Depachika" -Some side dishes bought in "Depachika" -Japanese sweets -Tea (You can take this tour as lunch) Capacity: Max6 The whole shops are your restaurant! Let’s enjoy eating and drinking in Takashimaya Nihonbashi
strTitle: Enjoy "Depachika" food tour at Nihonbashi Takashimaya

strIntroduction: It is very difficult to look for your favorite sake with Japanese label. An international Sake tasting expert explain the attractive point of Japanese traditional drinks Sake. For example how to know the information from label and sake breweries stories. Also it is important which sake ware choose. Please enjoy to taste about 3 kinds of sakes with beautiful and traditional sake wears. Time: The tour is 1 hour. From each 2:00pm, 3:00pm, 4:00pm Schedule: Team Building Explore liquors shop in underground floor Learn about Sake Buy some Sake If you want to see a sake cups and sake wares in 7th floor Taste sake in private room Capacity : Max 6
strTitle: Japanese Sake tour in Nihonbashi Takashimaya

strIntroduction: Tsukiji is the center of the Edo culture, which represents Tokyo. Tsukiji has made its name famous all over Japan as a treasure trove of delicious food and fresh materials and as the waterfront of Tokyo. Other attractive Edo cultures can also be found at Tsukiji, where delicious foods gather. It is a tourist area full of curious things for foreign people. This time, we would like to introduce a 3-hour course of Tsukiji area, where you can enjoy plenty of charms of the Edo culture. First, starting with Tsukiji Station! There are plenty of spots, which are filled with charms of Edo culture around Tsukiji Station: Tsukiji Honganji Temple, Tsukiji Curb Market, which is a major point of this tourist course, numerous famous sushi restaurants, and Bishoku Ginza (Gourmet Street), but they are only a few examples. When you wander into the back of the alleys, you'll fine more hidden famous shops. Come and explore the neighborhood, and find your original "Tsukiji." Time slip in the Edo era at Shinbashi Enbujō About a 10-minute walk from Tsukiji Station. You'll arrive at the center of traditional performing arts arranged in Kabukiza, Shinbashi Enbujō. At Shinbashi Enbujō, you can appreciate Kabuki, representing Japan. Speaking of Shinbashi Enbujō charms, you can watch a repertoire of Kabuki with a high threshold image from a minimum of 3,000 JPY and you can taste delicious sweets. Never forget to try Taiyaki with Shiratama and Ningyoyaki, which are sold inside Shinbashi Enbujo! Go to Hamarikyu Park and see the views of the waterfront Tsukiji! You arrive at Hamarikyu Park in about 15 minutes walk from Shinbashi Enbujō. Hamarikyu park is the villa of the waterfront, where the royal family used to come a long time ago. From the pond in the park, which barges into Tokyo Bay, you can see the views of Tokyo. As there are few obstacles there, you can feel the sky and the sea of Tokyo wider and can enjoy seasonal plants all year round. Eat all Edo gourmet at Tsukiji Curb Market! At the conclusion of the 3-hour tour, enjoy delicious Japanese seafood at a sushi restaurant near Tsukiji Market. The charm of Tokyo Sushi is located in the right ingredients. You can taste various flavors, texture, sound, and temperature when you eat, there is never the same taste repeated again.
strTitle: 60% OFF Find charms of Edo in Tokyo Tsukiji area

strIntroduction: Shikoku, Japan’s smallest and least populated main island situated below and between Hiroshima and Osaka, is famous for its udon noodles. Upon informing a Japanese friend of mine that I was headed there for a trip, he told me to try the udon as it was meant to be delicious. Udon, a thick wheat flour noodle usually served in a hot soup, is a Japanese cuisine enjoyed all over the country. Different regions across Japan are known for being particularly good at different cuisines, and it seems that the kind of udon is Shikoku. So with that, I travelled to Kotohira, in Shikoku’s Kagawa prefecture, to meet the local udon expert who operates under a service called “Udon Taxi” which, you guessed it, is literally a taxi that takes you to udon restaurants. We can pick you up at your hotel, station and airport in Kagawa. Then you go around to your favorite Udon resutaurants. If you don't know much about Udon restaurants, our driver will choose for you. You can choose between a 60-minute, a 90-minute and a 120-minute course. The pick-up locations are: Chu-san area (around Konpira), Kotohira Station, Marugame Station, Utazu Station, Sakaide Station, Takamatsu Airport.
strTitle: Ride the Udon Taxi around various Udon restaurants in Kagawa

strIntroduction: Pick up at Fukuyama Station or your accommodation in Fukuyama. We'll visit a house or community place and cook with locals. You can enjoy cooking together. Here is a sample menu: Temaki zushi, a kind of sushi. This is easy to cook and enjoyable to choose ingredients for, so it is common to cook at home in Japan. If you have any preference about the menu or the ingredients, please tell us. When the meal is ready, you say "Itadakimasu", a greeting before eating. Then let's eat together! Chat with locals, and enjoy cultural exchange.
strTitle: Try easy Japanese cooking with locals in Fukuyama

strIntroduction: In this tour we will visit little-known spots in Tokyo to appreciate public display of wonderful Ikebana art works. Meet at Tameike-Sanno subway station at 10:30 in the morning. Take a long outdoor escalator to climb up to Hie Shrine on top of the hill which is one of the hidden "power spots" surrounded by the prime minister's official residence and the Diet Building. Go down to the Capitol Hotel Tokyu to appreciate a gorgeous Ikebana work at the entrance lobby. Then lunchtime will be at a nice-view restaurant on the 27th floor in Sanno Park Tower (around 11:30 am). My recommendation is "vege-buffet lunch" served with 2 rice balls and miso soup (This lunch costs 1200 JPY per person). You can choose other food such as meat or fish, of course. After lunch, we will take a short subway ride to "Aoyama Itchome" station (costs 160 JPY) to visit Sogetsu building where we can enjoy beautiful Ikebana works in a traditional Japanese room as well as the outstanding art works by Isamu Noguchi in the entrance hall built in wellhole style. The view is also amazing there in that you can look down the vast forest of the Akasaka Detached Palace where the Crown Prince and other Japanese royal families currently live. Then, we'll head back to the subway station walking along the beautiful property of the palace. The tour ends around 2:00 pm at "Aoyama Itchome" Station (Tokyo metro / Toei Subway). It's about a 3.5-hour tour, but would not be too much of a walk. Just get relaxed, enjoy strolling in the pleasant area of Tokyo. This will be a small group tour for up to 6 people.
strTitle: Appreciate Ikebana and Hidden View Points in Tokyo

strIntroduction: In this day trip you will visit one of Japan's little known wonders and an object of worship for many Catholic pilgrims from all over the world: the Our Lady of Akita statue in the Chapel of Seitai Hoshikai in the outskirts of Akita city. While Japan's Christian heritage is well known in cities like Nagasaki and Hakodate where one can see majestic old churches and cathedrals, Akita's Chapel of Seitai Hoshikai is a hidden gem known mainly by devoted believers. The Chapel's architecture resembles a traditional Japanese temple but is a Catholic church inside. Surrounding the Chapen are two beautiful gardens that are worth a visit. The Chapel's most famous highlight is the holy wooden statue of the Our Lady of Akita, known for its miraculous weeping which happened a total of 101 times between 1975 and 1981 and has been documented on TV. In addition, the statue is said to have healed hearing impairment and caused other mystical phenomena like stigmata. You can visit the Our Lady of Akita on a day trip from Tokyo (Shinkansen tickets included in the tour price) or starting from Akita Station (no Shinkansen tickets included). Please choose your preferred option from the price menu. This tour will include a car transportation to and from Akita Station and a licensed guide who will show you around the Chapel and its gardens, explaining the history and significance of the statue. The Chapel of Seitai Hoshikai is open every day from 9 am to 11:30 am and from 13:00 pm to 16:30 pm between April and November, and from 10:00 am to 11:30 am and from 13:00 pm to 16:30 pm between December and March.
strTitle: See the miraculous Our Lady of Akita on a day trip

strIntroduction: Rent go-karts and enjoy driving them on the public roads in the countryside towns of Tokyo's closest neighbouring prefecture Saitama! Particularly suitable and convenient for guests and residents of the Yokota Air Base in West Tokyo! This is a wonderful and fun way of sightseeing, and a great day trip from Tokyo! Explore the historical and modern places of Saitama in a fascinating way! This is a self-guided kart-rental only plan. There will be no guide with your group, but you can find below several examples of popular routes in Saitama that you can ride around: Little Edo Kawagoe course (1 hour) Ride around the historical town and the old warehouses of Kawagoe between the castle residence, Hikawa Shrine and the Bell Tower! Saitama urban course(2-3 hours) Explore the urbanscape of the giant Saitama Super Arena, the Cocoon City and the quiet streets of Saitama Bonsai Gardens! Tokorozawa and Sayama course (3 and more hours) Ride around the countryside towns and see the Aviation Park, the baseball haven Seibu Dome, Sayama Lake and the longest avenue with Zelkova trees in Japan! You can rent a go-kart from 1 hour to up one whole day. Business hours: 9 am - 5 pm Note that the go-kart activity will not be available after 5 pm, therefore book earlier if you want to enjoy your entire requested time. For example, if you want to book a 2-hour tour, the latest possible time for booking will be 3 pm. Please note that: ※ You must have a valid Japanese drivers license, Japanese SOFA license, or International Driving Permit based on the 1949 Geneva Convention*. ※ Bring a valid Japanese drivers license, Japanese SOFA license, or International Driving Permit* and a copy of your passport (passport is not required for Japanese) to the shop on the day. ※ All karts are for 1-person. There are no multi-person karts. ※ You have to fill the tank up before you return the kart when you choose the long courses. ※ The height restriction: must be 150cm to 185cm. ※ Preferred 100 kg and less. Over 100kg: the kart won’t move as fast ※ The activity is cancelled only when it rains heavily. When the activity is cancelled due to bad weather, you will be able to re-schedule without charge. If the alternative date for re-scheduling due to bad weather is not available, you will get a full refund. ※Pregnant Drivers: It is possible for pregnant drivers to take part in this experience but the go-kart handle may hit the guest's tummy and it may be uncomfortable. It is possible to make a booking first and go to shop try to see if she can fit comfortably in the kart. If the pregnant guest cannot fit, a refund will be provided for the pregnant guest. ※ The insurance fee is included in the price. Third Party Liability = Unlimited Guest himself/herself = up to JPY 30,000,000 Disclaimer = JPY 50,000 ※ No helmets and no seatbelts are used. *Holders of a license from Belgium, France, Germany, Monaco, Slovenia, Switzerland or Taiwan can use an official Japanese translation provided by the Japan Automobile Federation (JAF) or the country’s embassy or consulate in Japan. We will promise you to make your trip unforgettable! Don't miss this chance!
strTitle: Rent Go-Karts and ride around Kawagoe Saitama!

strIntroduction: This 2-day-1-night tour lets you stay at Aizu's secluded Showa Hot Spring Shirakaba-so inn and travel freely around the Oku-Aizu area in your own taxi. See the stunning Oku-Aizu scenery, make traditional crafts, and experience the natural environment. Amikumi-zaiku is a traditional Oku-Aizu weaving craft passed down for 2500 years. See crafts that are called the "Hermès of the forest and Louis Vuitton of the mountain" and try weaving your own. This special tour lets you freely visit and experience Oku-Aizu sightseeing spots, such as the gorgeous scenery looking down on the Daiichi Tadamigawa Bridge and a tour of Enzoji Temple built 1200 years ago where the Akabeko red cow toy originated. The schedule of the tour is below: Day 1 Meet at designated stations or the airport. Full day touring Oku-Aizu (major spots in Yanaizu Town, Mishima Town, Kaneyama Town, Showa Village, and Tadami Town. Tour only includes Oku-Aizu.) After sightseeing, stay at the Showa Hot Spring Shirakaba-so inn. Day 2 Full day touring Oku-Aizu (major spots in Yanaizu Town, Mishima Town, Kaneyama Town, Showa Village, and Tadami Town. Tour only includes Oku-Aizu.)
strTitle: 2-day tour to the hot springs and local culture of Oku-Aizu

strIntroduction: Do you want to travel around enjoyable spots in Japan? This tour will take you to really enjoyable spots to experience Japanese traditional culture and rural life! On this tour we will visit Ogawa-machi town in Saitama prefecture, about 1 hour away form Tokyo. Ogawa-machi is well-known for Japanese traditional hand-made paper, Washi. It has history of about 1300 years inherited from the Nara era. Its manufacturing technique is designated as an important national cultural asset (intangible cultural heritage). But even though it is famous for washi, there are many other attractions in Ogawa-machi. So we will walk around to find them. First, we will visit a Washi handicraft studio to see how the paper is made. It is worth watching the process of making it at a real studio. Next, we will go to a Craft Center to see the variety of Japanese traditional handicrafts, and here you can make the paper by yourself and buy craft works for souvenir as well. Then, we will have free lunch time at Michi-no-Eki Ogawa-machi, the public facility where you can get local products. There you can eat soba or udon noodles at a reasonable price. After lunch, we will walk around the small rural town to see a temple, an old elementary school and so on. Then, we will climb a small mountain, Sengen-yama. There you can have a splendid view from a tall sightseeing tower on the top. If the weather is good, you can look down the whole town of Ogawa-machi surrounded by a large forest, and see famous majestic mountains, Nikko, Akagi, Haruna, Tsukuba, etc far away. And one more thing that will excite you is the 203-meter long Roller Slide. This slide was made from the local citizens to attract more people to the town. You can taste a bit of thrill as if you slide down in the air with the splendid view around! Lastly, we will drop by a liquor brewery of Japanese rice wine, sake. There you can see inside the brewery, and if you want, you can taste sake. Yes, you can have a really solid and enjoyable time! Even though you can't find those spots on guide books, it's surely worth visiting!! Come on and have fun with me, and a Little Monkey! strIntroduction: THE STAR STYLIST Creative producer, Horikawa has been making waves in the hairstyling world for over nineteen years, and has models and celebrities as customers. Here is his new work: (Picture 1 above: Horikawa with Japanese/English bilingual stylist (left) and receptionist(right) (Picture 2: Horikawa's design work) Horikawa's hair style creations are often featured in major magazines, commercials and on TV, but he is not overly concerned with getting fame for his work. Two things drive him the most - creating beauty through his craft and leaving his customers completely satisfied with their new look. THE STAR STYLE EXPERIENCE So what is it like to see this master stylist at work? We took our hair model over to Michio Nozawa Hair Salon in Ginza for the Chiaki Horikawa experience, and to see the hair designer's skills in action. As we walked into the salon, we were immediately impressed by its sleek, spotless and modern interior. We were welcomed by the friendly staff and by Horikawa himself; and soon our hair model was comfortably seated in a private room – a little anxious about the cut, but also eager to walk out of the salon with a brand new style. (Picture 3: The sleek interior at Michio Nozawa Hair Salon) Horikawa's consultation and expert hair analysis put all our hair model's anxieties at ease, and she was ready for her hair transformation to begin. THE COLOR As this was a first-time hair color experience for our hair model, she was rather nervous about the procedure, and had no idea what to expect. She wanted a color that complimented her skin tone and that didn't show an obvious growth line. Horikawa knew exactly what to do. He would make her hair one shade lighter than her original color, and combined with an ash tone, give her hair the most natural look possible. After he confirmed that she was happy with his decision, the coloring process was seamlessly carried out. Then it was time for the main event – Horikawa's execution of two unique and highly skilled haircuts: the Slide Cut and the Effect cut. THE SLIDE CUT To demonstrate the Slide Cut, Horikawa cut the hair in a sliding motion from root to tip, reducing hair volume without taking away any length. This cut makes thick coarse hair (common with Asian hair), easier to manage and gives hair a sleeker look. THE EFFECT CUT In the effect cut, he lifted up chunks of hair and cut it in light, downward strokes, repeating the technique until a 3-D effect was achieved. The underlying hair - now cut to a shorter length than the rest - gave the look more volume and softness at the crown; so this cut is perfect for those with straight, heavy hair that need a boost of life. THE RESULTS Horikawa's speed and superior skill level in the cutting techniques were amazing to see, and our hair model – unable to stop smiling at her new reflection in the mirror – was most impressed with her fantastic new look. (Picture 4: Both stylist and client completely satisfied!) The experience with Horikawa demonstrated "omakase" service in Japan perfectly, which means that clients can have total trust in his knowledge and expertise, and rest assured that their hair will be in good hands. (Picture 5: Her new look!)
strTitle: Star Style Hair Design in Ginza

strIntroduction: Do you want to travel around exciting spots in Japan? This tour will take you to really exciting but unknown spots to experience mysterious Japan. First, we will climb up a small mountain, Mt. Takatori, only 139-meter-high like a hill, but nice and fascinating. The mountain is composed of limestone rock, so you can see some rock climbers near the summit, and we can enjoy the rocky way like an adventure in the deep alpine nature. As we hike, you can find several attractions on the way. A Big Buddha image carved on rock wall like Bamiyan in Afghanistan is the most impressive sight. It stands in the middle of the mountain quietly. A medieval temple, Jinmuji, which has more than 1300 years of history, is also a refined sight. It makes you feel peaceful with its quiet atmosphere. It is said that the first samurai shogun, Minamoto Yoritomo, who established the ancient Kamakura government, also came to worship this temple. Of course, the view from the top is great! If the weather is good, you can have a 360-degree view including Tokyo Bay and Mt. Fuji far way. It's only a brief hiking for about 2 hours, but you will surely be excited! Second, we will explore a sacred cave of secret Buddhism, Taya Cave, which has been carved in ancient times for meditation training. Carrying a candle in your hand, you can find numerous splendid reliefs of Buddhism tales in the darkness of the cave: a dragon, crane, turtle, Chinese zodiac animals, Buddhism saints, Sanskrit characters, Mandala and so on. The corridors wind from chamber to chamber for about 1 km under the ground. You will surely be impressed and overwhelmed by this wonderful and mysterious heritage. Lastly, we will drop by a pottery gallery (ceramic art studio), Sueno-sato, for sightseeing and shopping. This gallery opened in an old Japanese traditional house to show Japanese traditional potteries. You can learn more about the Japanese sophisticated culture! Even though you can't find those spots on guide books, it's surely worth visiting!! Come on and have fun with me, and a Little Monkey! strIntroduction: This is a bus tour that will take you to the best spots to enjoy Tokyo by night. You will board a sightseeing bus at Hamamatsucho Bus Terminal at 17:40 and head to Rainbow Bridge, the suspension bridge that crosses Tokyo Bay into Odaiba area. It is about 798 meters in total length, and its main tower is 126 meters high, which is about as tall as a 40-story building. Once in Odaiba, you'll be able to do some shopping and explore the sights. From 18:30 to 18:50 you'll have a perfect photo opportunity with the replica of the Statue of Liberty and the Rainbow Bridge in the background. This replica was built after the commemoration of "The French Year in Japan" in 1998-1999, when the French Statue of Liberty located in Paris was brought to Japan temporarily. The tour will drive by the Tokyo Gate Bridge, resembling two dinosaurs having a face-off, which is why it earned the nickname "Dinosaur Bridge". The tour will then arrive to Kagaya restaurant at 19:30, where you will enjoy a delicious Japanese set meal. The tour will then move on to the Roppongi Hills Tokyo City View Observation Deck (20:50 - 21:40), where you'll enjoy breathtaking views of the Tokyo skyline, a great spot for romantics and photographers alike! The tour will end at Tokyo Station Marunouchi South exit at 22:00. this tour is provided by HIS
strTitle: Enjoy a Tokyo panoramic night bus tour with dinner

strIntroduction: This morning bus tour takes you to the famous sightseeing spots in Tokyo. It includes Meiji Jingu Shrine, the Imperial Palace East Gardens, and Asakusa Sensoji Temple. Make sure that you enjoy the view of Tokyo city from the bus window along with a multilingual audio guide. You'll first visit Meiji Jingu shrine. It's a Shinto shrine, commemorating Emperor Meiji and the Empress Shoken. Although the shrine is in the center of Tokyo, it's surrounded by forest offering people relaxation. The shrine holds ceremonies all year-round to wish the prosperity of the Imperial Family and the country, people's happiness and world peace. After seeing the National Diet Building from the bus window, it's time to explore the Imperial Palace East Gardens. The beauty of its nature and Japanese garden will impress you. The site of the Edo castle and exhibits will give you an opportunity to learn Japanese history and culture. When the Imperial Palace East Gardens are closed on Mondays, Fridays and December 23rd, the tour will visit the Imperial Palace Plaza, instead. The final destination is Sensoji Temple in Asakusa, where you will feel over 1,400 years of rich history. The magnificence of Kaminarimon gate, Hozomon gate and Five-storied Pagoda will take your breath away. On the way to Sensoji Temple, there is an opportunity to buy souvenirs at Nakamise shopping street, where you find souvenir shops and Japanese sweets shops. Enjoy your time at Sensoji Temple, the oldest temple in Tokyo. The tour ends in Ginza. It's possible to explore the city of Ginza in the afternoon. Enjoy the rest of your day!! Here is the tour itinerary. 9:00 Departure from Hamamatsucho Bus Terminal Meiji Jingu shrine (30 minutes) National Diet Building (from the bus window) Imperial Palace East Gardens (45 minutes) Sensoji Temple and Nakamise shopping street Ginza (Drive through) Japanese Dance Viewing (10 min) 13:15 The tour ends in Ginza. Although the tour is operated daily, early reservation is recommended to ensure your seat. this tour is provided by HIS
strTitle: Explore Meiji Jingu shrine and the Imperial Palace in Tokyo!

strIntroduction: This afternoon tour covers the Asakusa area in Tokyo where you can relax on a tour bus and get the opportunity to enjoy the drive-by sightseeing through the bus windows. The bus passes by the Imperial Palace, National Diet Building, Ginza and Akihabara. The highlight of the tour will be visiting the Sensoji Temple and Tokyo SkyTree which is almost like time travel from the past to the present. Sensoji Temple in Asakusa is the oldest temple in Tokyo, with about 1,400 years of rich history. After Kaminarimon gate, where there is a big red lantern, enjoy a stroll around Nakamise shopping street where you'll find souvenir shops and Japanese sweet shops. Hozomon gate, a five-storied pagoda and a Buddha statue in the main hall are all must-sees!! In 2011, the Guinness World Records officially approved Tokyo Skytree, with a height of 634 meters, as the tallest tower in the world. This latest well-known tower holds 2 observation decks, Tembo Deck (at 350 meters high) and Tembo Galleria (at 450 meters high). The tour takes you to the Tembo Deck, which is covered with 5 meter-high glass for a 360-degree all-around view. The scenery from the Tembo Deck is thrilling, enormous and unforgettable. It's fun to look for Mt. Fuji on clear days. The tour only includes the admission to the Tembo Deck. Please be noted that it doesn't visit the Tembo Galleria. Here is the tour itinerary: 13:40 Departure from Hamamatsucho Bus Terminal Drive-by Sightseeing: the Imperial Palace, National Diet Building, State Guest House, Ginza and Akihabara. Sensoji Temple and Nakamise shopping street (50 minutes) Tokyo Skytree Tembo Deck (80 minutes) 19:40 The tour ends at Hamamatsucho Bus Terminal. Although the tour is operated daily, early reservation is recommended to ensure your seat. Pickup Time & Location 13:05 Ana Intercontinental Tokyo 13:15 Grand Prince New Takanawa 13:40 Hamamatsucho Bus Terminal Hato Bus Station near World Trade Center Building at South Exit 12:15 Hilton Tokyo 12:40 Hotel Grand Palace 12:50 Hotel New Otani Main building - hotel lobby 12:20 Hyatt Regency Tokyo 13:10 Imperial Hotel Tokyo Main building - hotel lobby 12:30 Keio Plaza Hotel Tokyo 13:20 Shiba Park Hotel 13:10 Shinagawa Prince Hotel Main building - hotel lobby 14:10 Tokyo Station Hato Bus Stop at Marunouchi South Exit This tour is provided by HIS [Remarks] 1. If the minimum number of participants (1) is not met by 4 days before the scheduled date, the tour on that date may be cancelled. 2. When visiting Tokyo Skytree®, participants board and exit the bus at an outdoor stop. It may take about 5 minutes to walk between Tokyo Skytree® and the stop. 3. This tour does not visit the 450 m high Tembo Galleria. 4. In case of strong winds or for other reasons, the elevators of Tokyo Skytree® may be halted and the observation deck may have shortened hours or be closed. In each of these cases, entrance fees for the observation deck may be refunded, and the tour itinerary may be changed. 5. The child booking rate applies for children 4 years and older. 6. Children age 3 and younger may participate for free, but will not be provided with their own bus seats and must sit on the lap of their parent or guardian. strTitle: Explore Tokyo SkyTree and Asakusa Sensoji Temple, Tokyo!

strIntroduction: This seven hour tour starts at your centrally located Osaka hotel, and includes a stop for lunch at a kaiten sushi (revolving sushi) restaurant. First stop is Osaka Castle, where you'll explore the expansive grounds and take in the grandeur of the castle itself. Time for you to enter the castle can be made upon request, with the admission charge being at your own expense. For most people, going inside this mid-20th century replica is worth a miss. After the castle, it's off to Shitennoji we'll go. This 6th century Buddhist complex features numerous notable buildings, including a five story pagoda. It's also the home of our first garden stop, "Honbo Teien." It's a beautiful, uncrowded, peaceful stop. Shifting gears, we head to Sumiyoshi Taisha, founded in the third century. This is considered by many to be the most important Shinto shrine in Japan, and it's distinctive architecture is a sight to behold. By now you should be good and ready for a sushi lunch, so we'll make a stop at a local kaiten sushi (known to some as "sushi-go-round") restaurant. After that, we'll still have time to explore Nagai Park's expansive botanical gardens. Depending on the season, you could be in for a variety of treats in this sprawling living museum that surrounds a small lake. After all this sightseeing, you may be glad to be dropped back off at your hotel for some rest. Alternatively, you can be dropped off anywhere else in central Osaka to continue exploring on your own. Note that you will be driven around in a 4-door sedan, which means three guests can be seated very comfortably, or a total of four people can be accommodated if one person is willing to sit in the middle of the back seat.
strTitle: Explore Osaka's Castle, Gardens and Temples by Private Car

strIntroduction: Kamakura became the capital of Japan (1185-1333), known as the little Kyoto. It was a Samurai era and the location was selected as the capital since it was surrounded by mountain and it was not easy to be approached by enemy (a natural fort). Therefore, we can find good hiking courses in Kamakura and visit a few of the famous temples on the way. Kamakura is located one hour away from Tokyo by train. You can visit one of the ancient cities in Japan on this tour. Below is the schedule of the tour: 9:00 Meet at your hotel 10:30 JR Kita-Kamakura Station 11:30 Zeniarai Benten (Money washing temple) 12:00 Lunch 13:30 Daibutsu (Big Buddha) 14:30 Hachimangu (the shrine) 15:30 JR Kamakura Station 17:00 Go back to your hotel
strTitle: Embark on a Kamakura hiking tour
